Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 05:40PM KCmama wrote: My shirts are UnderArmour, women's, long sleeve (wicking), in one size too small.  I noticed a difference in the compression based on the color - the lighter colors have less compression, so I chose an even smaller size for the white shirt I have. I wash them in a lingerie bag, then hang them to dry.  The ones I put through the drier lost their compression a bit after even the first wash. They are absolutely not a fashion statement.  They are boring and look weird, since I wear them inside out.  It's not bad as a layered look, but that's more for fall or winter, not summer.

Posts.Content: KCmama wrote: Just got back from my LE appt and thought I'd share some good news.  My LE has some swelling, but more than that, a lot of discomfort throughout my breast, trunk, back, and arms - even from only a little swelling.  This past weekend, my oldest got married, and I wore sleeveless dresses for all events. I often had my compression sleeve on, but less than usual, and felt pretty uncomfortable by evening. Our Dallas weather is humid and hot, and my 2x/day MLD didn't seem to be making a dent. I have not been taught to wrap yet, probably since my swelling is mostly under control. (I will be learning this soon).  I have sports compression shirts here, which I wear here and there, as well, and do pretty well with them.  This weekend, I decided to sleep in my compression shirts, since I usually don't sleep in any compression at all. What a difference!  I wear them inside out, since the seams scratch my sensitive skin.  At my LE appt, the therapist noticed right away that my armpit and back are the best they've been so far.  I know each of us is different, and what works for one may not work for another. I still have to figure out what I'm going to do during the days, and I need to learn to wrap at night. There is SO much to learn for me to feel like I really understand this.  And I felt like this one little positive thing gave me hope.  Sleeping in a compression shirt is not hard or uncomfortable, and it's working well for me, at least for now.  Compression sleeve by day, sports shirt by night. Happy dancing here.    Dx 12/12/2009, DCIS, 2cm, Grade 1, 0/7 nodes, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2010 10:26PM KCmama wrote: I'm in Dallas, so I understand the concerns about UnderArmour's long sleeves.  I wouldn't have believed it, but if my a/c is on, my arm and body are very cool.  If I layer something on top of the shirt, it reduces the wicking capabilities, and I am warmer.  I have been wearing my shirts beneath sundresses. It does look a bit odd - long sleeves, and all - but for me, it's really helped a lot with my truncal issues.  With the correct size for me, my arms are compressed too.  If you are unsure, purchase one and see how it does.  I have a local sports store which has a good selection, so I've just tried one size at a time.  Immediately after surgery, I was swollen and tender, so I needed a larger side. Now my swelling is down and my tenderness is less, so I can take a bit more compression, so I'm now wearing a smaller size during the day, but my larger sizes at night.  My LE swelling is not severe, so it able to be controlled with the UA shirts and 2x/day MLD.  Compression sleeves are used if my outfit can't accomodate the UA shirt, but those sleeves do not help support my truncal issues.  There are other options - the binders, swell spots, etc, so if UA does not work for you, you've still got other avenues.

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2010 12:38PM KCmama wrote: When we flew a few weeks ago, I was ticked that they pulled me out of line, put me in a side room to wait for a security person to come, then had be walk over to the other side so they could do a "sample" swab of my terrorizing compression sleeve to make sure I was not dangerous.  This took WAY too much time!!  Not to mention that people stare and wonder.  In this first side room, it was me and the little grandma with titanium knee replacements.  Lovely.  I decided the next time I fly, I'm wearing a long sleeved shirt over my sleeves, and I'll pull my gauntlet off when I take my shoes off, so I'll be without for a total of about 3 minutes.  Long sleeves, long sleeves, long sleeves.  what a pain!
